Spark The Challenge!
Play for Everyone!
Ready, Set, Learn!
You will be able to:
• Talk about ways kids play differently and why some children may need help to play.
• Share ideas on how to make play fair and fun for everyone.
• Show kindness by thinking about what other kids might need to feel happy and included. • Name one or two things that make a playground good for all children.
• Look at shapes, colors, and natural things like sand and plants to see how they make playgrounds fun for everyone.
• Measure and compare spaces and materials to find out which ones are safe and good for play.
2

The sun was shining as
Ms. Sara’s class arrived at the park for their trip. The students ran to the playground, excited to play. Adam and Laila laughed as
they raced to the jungle gym.
Laila looked sad: “Khaled,
why aren’t you playing?”
Khaled sighed: “I want to… but the ramps are too steep, and I can’t get on the
slide.”
Adam looked around: “That’s not fair! Everyone should be able to play!”
Laila nodded: “We need to fix this. What if we make a
playground where everyone can play, even you?”
Khaled smiled: “Really? That would be great!”

Let’s
Think!
Let’s Design a Playground!
• Look at the photo of the empty playground. • Your teacher will give you pictures of fun things to add—like swings, slides, and trees!
• You can also draw your own ideas using crayons or markers. Use your imagination!
Think about: • What shapes and colors do you want to use?
• What natural things could make it better—like sand, water, or plants?
• What will make the playground fun, safe, and welcoming for all kids? • Now glue on the pictures—or draw—what you think fits best!
Helpful tips:
• Pick things that are soft, strong, or give shade. • Think about all kids—including kids who use wheelchairs, kids who like to swing, or those who need a quiet spot.
